I was a competitive swimmer from age 7 through collegiate Division 1 athletics, and this video really struck a chord. Nearly every swimmer I knew (myself included...) who excelled between ages 10-14 became obsolete by the end of high school and in college. On the other hand, the kids who got into the sport around age 12-13 or transitioned into it as a teenager, really peaked in their college years, when it actually matters.

Why in this almost 8min video of “does hard work really matter?” is there no mention of if hard work really matters??

This is one of the most corrupt, vacuous presentation of an idea I have ever seen.

Do genetics matter? Of course, that is literally news to not a single person who is watching this.

Does circumstance matter? Of course, again, that is not news to a single person watching this.

Also, neither of those questions even remotely answer the question posed. It is total obfuscation and answers to a completely separate question, I.e. “what are the components of success?”. There is not a human being on the planet that thinks the only variable is hard work. There a very few people who even think hard work is the main component. Easiest way to illustrate this to anyone is just pointing out, no matter how hard you work, if you’re 5’3”, you’re not going to be a NFL defensive end. Just not going to happen.

If you were interested in answering your own question you would look at a study that samples similar populations that are targeting the same goal and see how their level of work effects the ultimate outcome. Then you would have an answer to “does hard work matter?”.

Your genetics you’re born with, nothing you can do. Your circumstances (especially at birth) are not anything you can exert any control over either, there’s nothing you can do. Your work ethic and effort is the biggest component under your control that you can alter. I was interested clicking on this video to see what effect that could have.

If you have any desire to help people at all I’d suggest you make that video. Because right now your video is unnecessarily the most depressing, demoralizing video I have ever seen. While also not even answering the question posed, so it seems almost intentional. To be “accepting” and to not “offend” you’re basically just telling people who are unhappy with their situation, “oh the people doing better, don’t worry, they didn’t earn it, stop trying, you were not born to do the thing you enjoy”. What sort of message is that?!

If my sport was basketball (it’s not), and I was not good but really enjoyed it. Id much rather hear “if you put in the top 1% of effort, you could become good enough to make your highschool varsity team”. Then hear the message, “Someone of Lebron’s natural talent only has to put in 50% effort to Division 1 athlete and if you try the hardest possible you’ll never make it anyways, so don’t put in the work”.

I know it’s not intended. But this video strikes me as one of the most soulless, immoral, malicious videos I have seen. I literally cannot think of a better video to make children, or really anyone in a bad situation, give up and not try to put in the effort to improve themselves. Even if the correlation with effort and success was 0% (which I know for a fact it isn’t), I’d still rather hold on to the myth, because the alternative is deterministic nihilism. Boy did I hate this video.

This reminds me of the case with the feral child.

A child who was basically deprived of human contact for years. Because of isolation, the child never learned how to speak or form words. Even after being reintegrated into society, the child was unable to ever fully grasp a first language.

This makes me think that because people have different circumstances/environments, what they’re exposed to in childhood either unlocks, “soft-locks”, or locks one’s ability to advance in a particular field. In the child’s case, after a certain amount of time, her ability to speak was “locked”.

Which makes me think about poorer families who don’t always have the financial ability to enroll their children in extracurricular activities. Perhaps because some children never have the opportunity to play musical instruments as a child, it “soft locks” their ability to ever excel in an instrument, because they’ve spent so many years never developing the skills to play an instrument.

Of course, because music is common, the entire instrument skill line is never completely absent from someone’s life, anyone could probably learn how to play an instrument later in life, but would probably never become a prodigy or master because of the crucial connections that have to be made at adolescence.

The sampling period factor makes a lot of sense; people who engage in a wide variety of activities have more activities to choose from (as obvious a statement as you could make) and so have a better chance to find the particular thing that they're not just good at but will excel at. Excellence and mastery isn't just a matter of talent plus practice, it also involves intense interest, an alignment of personal values which can provide intrinsic motivation to persist in the activity (eg a teacher who values lifelong learning or an athlete who values healthy competition), and the opportunity to be appropriately challenged in order to develop their skill. Along with skill level, those things also happen to be the ingredients for getting into a "flow" state, which is often where people perform at their peak. I would be interested to see correlations between children with a broad activity sampling and the likelihood of experiencing frequent flow states in their chosen field or activity of expertise.

When I was a teenager I showed some talent for art, I had a particular interest in figure drawing and creating characters. My family and teachers were really keen for me to become some great illustration artist and become famous and make lots of money selling my beautiful masterpieces. At the time I didn't really have any idea what I wanted to do with my life, so I was like, "Yeah, art is totally a thing I want to do with my life, heh-heh, heh-heh."

So, I practiced... and I learned about anatomy, color theory, and composition. But... something was wrong. I wasn't really driven to create anything more than a simple sketch. I had no goal, no vision. By time I was 25 I realized I didn't really want to do art.

I realized that along with "talent" and "skill" you had to actually WANT to do the thing you're trying to be good at. At least, you have to want to be good at it. Some people mistake a passing interest for *passion*.

And that's okay, just don't get so hung up on it that you waste 17 years trying to drive yourself in that direction only to realize you don't actually want that for your life and end up wondering what to do with your life now that you no longer have that "goal" to work towards.

Professional classical violinist here.  I hate to break it to you, but it isn't "talent" that creates most "talented" musicians.  It's hard work.  Hard work beats "talent" every single time.  We may think, oh this kid/adolescent/adult is so TALENTED... but if you look closer, they all spend many hours a day practicing their craft.  Sure, some people are innately more gifted than others.  But a gifted musician who does not practice will always fail next to a less gifted musician who works very hard.  Those who are more innately gifted may trend towards practicing more, because they see immediate feedback from their work.  Those who are innately less gifted may feel practice is frustrating, and not work as hard, therefore, not progress as far.  As someone who teaches classical music, I know for a fact that those who spend more time in the practice room beat those who don't almost every single time.

It's absurd how the concept of 10000 hours has been so misunderstood and taken out of context. In the book Outliers, from which the idea of 10000 hours stemmed from, Malcolm Gladwell talks explicitly about how circumstances skew outcomes. For example, 40% of players in the NHL have birthdays between January and March and only 10% between October and December. The age cut offs in the junior leagues meant that kids whose birthdays were between January and March had almost an entire year of physical growth and coordination over the Oct.-Dec. kids so they would be funneled into elite leagues from the start which would make drastic differences in the long term.
